awd_abstract_narration: Interfacing laboratory instruments with microcomputers has                 become a requirement for successful scientific investigations.                  The introductory, sophomore course teaches laboratory science                   students to use a commercially available computer-based data                    acquisition and analysis system.  The experimental system                       includes a PC that is configured to be a stand-alone, digital                   oscilloscope, spectrum analyzer and data logger.  The course                    introduces the student to instrumentation, principles of of                     measurement, data acquisition, data analysis and communication of               results.  These are expected to be applicable for the forseeable                future.  This also prepares the students to participate as a team               member with engineers and computer scientists.  The grantee                     provides funds for this project that are an equal match for the                 NSF award.
